While there is no guaranteed way to prevent diabetic retinopathy, there are some steps you can take to reduce your risk and slow its progression if you already have it. These include:

1. Control your blood sugar levels: High blood sugar levels can damage blood vessels in the retina, leading to retinopathy. By keeping your blood sugar levels in a healthy range through diet, exercise, and medication if necessary, you can reduce your risk of developing diabetic retinopathy.

2. Manage your blood pressure and cholesterol: High blood pressure and high cholesterol can also contribute to retinopathy, so it's important to keep these levels under control as well.

3. Quit smoking: Smoking can damage blood vessels throughout the body, including those in the eyes, so quitting smoking can help reduce your risk of diabetic retinopathy.

4. Exercise regularly and maintain a healthy weight: Regular exercise and a healthy weight can help you maintain good overall health, which can reduce your risk of developing diabetic retinopathy.

5. Get regular eye exams: Regular eye exams can help detect diabetic retinopathy early, which can improve your chances of successful treatment.

While lifestyle changes may not completely prevent diabetic retinopathy from occurring or progressing, they can help reduce your risk and improve your overall health. It's important to discuss any changes to your diet or exercise routine with your doctor before making them.
